title: About
text: Hi, my name is Caroline Cummings! I am a Senior studying Computer Science with a concentration in AI. I am excited to learn about the applications of using LLMs to improve the quality and efficiency of tasks in everyday life.

title: Getting Started with GPT4All
text:
Local LLMs are great when you want privacy, offline access, or the freedom to experiment without an API key. GPT4All is a friendly desktop app that lets you download and chat with hundreds of open models—from lightweight 3–8B assistants to niche coding or multilingual variants—right on your machine.
Installing the GPT4All app typically takes less than 5 minutes and once you launch it you can explore all the models they have to offer.







Best for: Tiny footprint, quick drafts, “always-on” helper on modest hardware.
Why it’s neat: Strong quality for its size; offered in 4K and 128K context variants.





Best for: General chat + reasoning at 7B scale; a solid baseline many people compare against.
Note: Community-standard workhorse; the Instruct flavor is a tuned chat model.





Best for: Multilingual tasks & coding-friendly chat with modern tuning.
Why it’s neat: Qwen2/2.5 report strong results across language understanding, generation, coding, and reasoning.





Best for: Longer context experiments and a widely supported 8B option.
Trade-off: A step up in memory/compute vs. 7B, but you get a newer training run and longer context window.






1) Start with your hardware.

Low RAM / older CPU? Begin with Phi-3 Mini (Q4) for responsiveness.
8–16 GB+ and patient? Try Mistral 7B Instruct (Q4/Q5) or Qwen2(.5) 7B Instruct for a quality bump.
Room to spare / longer docs? Experiment with Llama-3.1-8B Instruct (longer context).

2) Match the task.

General writing/assistant: Mistral 7B, Llama-3.1-8B.
Small + snappy: Phi-3 Mini.
Multilingual/coding: Qwen2/2.5 7B.

3) Pick a quantization.

Q4 loads faster and uses less RAM; Q5 trades a bit more memory for a quality bump.
In GPT4All, you’ll see these as different downloads of the same model—grab Q4 first, upgrade if you need more fidelity.

4) Keep an eye on context length.

If you paste long readings or transcripts, prefer models that ship 8K–128K contexts (e.g., Phi-3 128K, Llama-3.1-8B).





GGUF is a compact binary format optimized for local inference (fast loading/saving) used by runners like llama.cpp. You’ll see many models offered as *.gguf downloads in GPT4All’s browser and on Hugging Face. You don’t have to do anything special—just download and run—but it’s why these models feel snappy on CPU.





It feels slow. Try a smaller model (3–4B), a more aggressive quantization (Q4), or reduce context length in GPT4All settings.
Out-of-memory errors. Close other heavy apps, use Q4, or choose a smaller parameter count.
macOS specifics. Official docs currently list Monterey 12.6+ as the target for the macOS build, and performance is best on Apple Silicon; CPU-only still works—just pick smaller models.
Need lots of models? GPT4All’s browser surfaces a huge catalog so you can trial multiple flavors side-by-side.

title: Testing Two AI Art Models: Gemini vs. Flux.1-dev
text:
Testing Two AI Art Models: Gemini vs. Qwen Image
I tried running the same prompts through two different image generation models — Google’s Gemini 2.5 Flash and the open-source Flux.1-dev — just to see how they’d interpret the same ideas.
For the “cozy café on a rainy street corner” prompt, Gemini added people into the scene. They looked a little animated, almost hazy, which gave it a softer, storybook vibe. Flux.1-dev went the opposite direction: darker streets, no people, and warm glowing lights from inside the café. It felt moodier, maybe more atmospheric.
 
Then I tried “a sunflower field in Van Gogh style.” Here Gemini really nailed the painterly feel — thick strokes, swirly textures, very recognizable Van Gogh energy. Flux.1-dev leaned more cartoon-like, but still clearly borrowed from Van Gogh’s palette and angle.
 
It’s worth noting that Flux.1-dev is open source, which means it’s more hackable, customizable, and shaped by the community. Gemini feels a bit more polished and accurate out of the box, but less flexible under the hood. Together, the differences highlight what’s exciting (and sometimes unpredictable) about experimenting with AI art tools.

title: Trying DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-7B: A Tiny Spanish Test
text:
I installed GPT4All and tried DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-7B with a minimal exchange to see if it would follow a strict translation instruction in Spanish. I was interested in testing the multilingual knowledge of this model which I read it was pretty good at.



This model thought for 53 seconds! One thing I thought was cool about using this model was that it provided the chain-of-thought reasoning for this response and what it was doing for those 53 seconds. I think when compared to a cloud-based LLM, like ChatGPT 5, it was MUCH slower. However, still fairly accurate for this translation task. 




Core instruction: translate to English while preserving names and numbers (I also care about keeping 24-hour time if the source uses it, and preserving accents).
What went well

Kept the date 3 and the room number 2.
Natural English, clear and readable.

What to improve

Dropped the accent in García and wavered between “room” vs “hall” without being asked.

title: Airplane Mode: Prompting DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-7B on a Plane
text:
Today I was reading my book, Superagency, on a plane ride where I had no service or WiFi.
I came across a word that I didn’t know the meaning of: sacrosanct. A couple months ago I would have acknowledged that I didn’t know the word and kept reading because I did not have access to the internet, a dictionary, or ChatGPT to look up the word.
However, today I remembered that I had gotten the GPT4All desktop app onto my computer last week and downloaded an LLM locally onto my computer: DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-7B.
I pulled out my computer with hopes that the model was truly runnable offline. To my joy, I opened the app and loaded the model into the chat.

User: What does the word sacrosanct mean?
Model: “Sacrosanct” is an adjective that describes something of great importance or authority, often beyond human contestation. It comes from the Latin words “sacer” (meaning priest) and “sanctorum” (a sacred place). In religious contexts, it refers to things held in highest spiritual regard, such as the Eucharist in Christianity or the Kaaba in Islam.

Wow! I was so happy that I had this powerful tool at my fingertips to converse with high up in the sky.
I kept my computer open while I continued to read and came across another word that I did not know:

User: What does the word equanimity mean?
Model: Equanimity means emotional balance; calmness and composure, especially in difficult circumstances. It refers to being able to remain peaceful and unruffled despite challenges or stresses. For example, someone with equanimity might handle criticism gracefully or stay composed during a heated debate. Synonyms: calmness, composure, stability
Examples: - The leader maintained equanimity even when the crisis escalated. - Her quiet demeanor suggested she had achieved a state of equanimity after years of struggle.

This time the model thought for 26 seconds before responding and I was able to see the chain of thought reasoning which I thought was very cool:
Alright, the user asked about "sacrosanct" earlier and I explained it. 
Now they're asking about "equanimity." 
They might be studying vocabulary or preparing for an exam.

I should provide a clear definition of equanimity. 
It's important to explain that it means emotional balance without getting upset by things, 
especially in tough situations.

Maybe include some synonyms like calmness and composure to help them understand better. 
Also, adding examples could make the explanation more concrete—like how people use it 
when dealing with stress or conflicts.

I should keep the tone friendly but informative since they're likely looking 
for a precise meaning without any fluff.
The last question I asked during my reading session was the following. The model thought for 60 seconds for this one! When I looked at the thought process, I realized that I had spelled “psychotherapies” wrong and it was trying to decipher my question.

User: What are some examples of pyschotherapies?
Model: Here are some examples:

Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT): A widely used psychotherapeutic technique that focuses on identifying and changing negative thought patterns and behaviors.
Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT): A therapy designed to help individuals with borderline personality disorder improve their interpersonal skills, reduce harmful behaviors, and manage symptoms of mental health disorders.
Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR): Also known as processing trauma, this technique uses eye movements combined with memory retrieval to treat post-traumatic stress symptoms.

If you meant something else by “psychotherapies,” please provide more context so I can give a more accurate response!

Overall, I was really impressed by the models responses. I think it was especially cool that it provided the thought process explaination alongside the output like the frontier LLMs now do. I am excited to continue to explore its capabilities!

title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple…
But it is possible you first said green (don’t worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It’s a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | — | — | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get’s it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. 🟪

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I’ll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: Asking Chat how to fix a toilet
text:
Sometimes AI feels abstract — answering questions about philosophy, coding, or writing. But when my sister showed ChatGPT 5 a picture of her toilet and requested help fixing it, the LLM was able to troubleshoot and lead her to a solution.
She noticed that the left hinge on her TOTO toilet seat had come loose. Instead of searching through manuals or calling a plumber, she simply snapped a photo and asked ChatGPT: “The left hinge here is loose, how do I fix?”

ChatGPT 5 responded with clear, step-by-step instructions (plus additional information that I omitted):

Lift the hinge cover
Locate the screw/bolt
Tighten the screw
Snap the hinge cover back down

She successfully fixed her toilet!
This small exchange highlights that AI isn’t only for complex reasoning tasks — it can also provide practical, accessible troubleshooting in everyday life.

title: Finding Philly’s Hidden Gems with Gemini
text:
As I approach the end of my college career in Philadelphia, I’ve realized that while I’ve seen the major tourist highlights, there’s so much more to this city. I’ve walked past the Liberty Bell, admired the art at the PMA, and gotten lost in the mosaics of the Magic Gardens. But with only a few months left, I wanted to go beyond the postcard destinations and discover the unique, lesser-known spots that make Philly so special. So, I turned to an unconventional source for recommendations: an AI assistant named Gemini.


A search for “Philly hidden gems” on Google yields countless articles, but they can be repetitive and sometimes feature places that are now quite popular. I wanted a curated list that took into account a massive amount of data and filter it based on my specific criteria—namely, that I’m a college student looking for unique experiences. I also wanted to see if an AI could understand the nuance of my request and provide genuinely helpful, non-obvious suggestions.


Gemini’s response was a pleasant surprise. It didn’t just rattle off a list of places; it categorized them into “Museums & Cultural Gems,” “Parks & Outdoor Spaces,” and “Unique Experiences.” This structure made the information easy to digest and prioritize.




The Mütter Museum: For something truly unique, this is a must-see. Located in the College of Physicians of Philadelphia, this museum is a fascinating and sometimes macabre collection of medical oddities, anatomical specimens, and antique medical instruments. It’s a journey into the history of medicine that is unlike any other museum experience.
The Barnes Foundation: While the PMA is a staple, the Barnes Foundation offers a different kind of art experience. It houses one of the world’s most significant collections of Impressionist, Post-Impressionist, and early Modern paintings, displayed exactly as Dr. Barnes arranged them. It’s an intimate and visually stunning collection.
Eastern State Penitentiary: A popular spot, but if you haven’t been, it’s a powerful and unique experience. This historic former prison is a hauntingly beautiful ruin with a rich history, including housing famous criminals like Al Capone. The audio tour provides an excellent and in-depth look at the prison’s past.
Shofuso Japanese House and Garden: Tucked away in Fairmount Park, this is a beautiful and serene escape from the city. The traditional 17th-century style Japanese house and its tranquil garden, complete with a koi pond and waterfall, offer a peaceful and reflective experience. It’s particularly stunning in the spring and fall.
Wagner Free Institute of Science: This museum is a perfectly preserved example of a Victorian-era natural history museum. The exhibits, which include over 100,000 specimens of fossils, minerals, and taxidermy, are displayed in their original wood and glass cases. It’s a step back in time and a fantastic hidden gem.



Bartram’s Garden: As the oldest surviving botanical garden in North America, this is a beautiful and historic spot on the banks of the Schuylkill River. It’s a perfect place for a walk, a picnic, and to learn about the history of American botany.
The Rail Park: Philadelphia’s version of New York’s High Line, this is an elevated park built on a former train line. It’s a great spot for a walk with unique views of the city’s post-industrial landscape.
Cira Green: A park on top of a parking garage. It’s a great spot to relax, have a picnic, and enjoy a unique and free view of the city skyline, especially at sunset.
Laurel Hill Cemetery: While a cemetery might seem like an unusual suggestion, this is a 78-acre National Historic Landmark and the nation’s second oldest cemetery. It’s a beautiful, sprawling park with incredible Victorian-era monuments and stunning views of the Schuylkill River.



Bok Bar: If it’s the right season (April to October), head to the top of the former Bok Vocational High School in South Philly. This seasonal bar offers an incredible rooftop view of the city skyline and is a great spot to grab a drink and hang out with friends.
South Street Headhouse District: You’ve been to the Magic Gardens, but explore the rest of the neighborhood. South Street is known for its eclectic shops, diverse restaurants, and vibrant murals. It’s a great place to wander and people-watch.
The Italian Market: America’s oldest outdoor market. The street is a feast for the senses, with vendors selling fresh produce, meats, cheeses, and a variety of Italian and other ethnic foods. It’s a bustling and authentic Philadelphia experience.
Walk or Bike the Schuylkill River Trail: The Schuylkill Banks Boardwalk offers a beautiful path over the water with a unique perspective of the city. You can walk, run, or bike for miles and explore different parts of the city’s riverfront.
Explore Local Neighborhoods: Spend some time wandering through neighborhoods like Fishtown for its vibrant arts and music scene, East Passyunk for its amazing food, or Queen Village for its charming, historic streets.






The recommendations were not only accurate but also thoughtfully tailored to my request. It provided a list that delved into the more authentic, local-centric experiences that I was looking for. Its ability to suggest a range of activities, from the macabre to the serene, and from hidden museums to vibrant neighborhoods, shows that it can synthesize information in a way that’s genuinely useful.
Although I had already visited quite a few places on this list, there are plenty of options to choose from that I have not been to before like the Mütter Museum or the Barnes Foundation, Shofuso Japanese House and Garden or the Rail Park.
I now have a fantastic itinerary for my last few months, and I’m looking forward to crossing these unique spots off my Philadelphia bucket list.

title: Finding Philly’s Hidden Gems with Gemini
text:
The recommendations were not only accurate but also thoughtfully tailored to my request. It provided a list that delved into the more authentic, local-centric experiences that I was looking for. Its ability to suggest a range of activities, from the macabre to the serene, and from hidden museums to vibrant neighborhoods, shows that it can synthesize information in a way that’s genuinely useful.
Although I had already visited quite a few places on this list, there are plenty of options to choose from that I have not been to before like the Mütter Museum or the Barnes Foundation, Shofuso Japanese House and Garden or the Rail Park.
I now have a fantastic itinerary for my last few months, and I’m looking forward to crossing these unique spots off my Philadelphia bucket list.

title: Giving ChatGPT Ingredients for a Baking Recipe
text:
I wanted to see how well ChatGPT 5 could improvise in the kitchen. Instead of asking for a standard recipe, I gave it a list of what I had on hand in my pantry and requested a simple recipe using only the ingredients I gave it.




Here’s what I told ChatGPT I had available:

Flour

White sugar
Brown sugar
Powdered sugar
Eggs

Vegan butter

Vanilla extract

Cocoa powder
Baking powder
Baking soda
Chocolate chips
Cornstarch
Soy milk
Half a container of strawberries
Rolled oats
Quick oats
Yeast
Cinnamon
Salt





ChatGPT gave me THREE options! It gave me options for One-Bowl Cocoa Brownies, Strawberry Oat Crisp, and Chewy Oatmeal Chocolate Chip Cookies. I decided to try out the first brownie recipe:

🍫 Option 1: One-Bowl Cocoa Brownies (Dairy-Free)
Ingredients

½ cup vegan butter, melted
1 cup white sugar (or half white, half brown for chewiness)
2 eggs
1 tsp vanilla extract
½ cup cocoa powder
½ cup flour
¼ tsp baking powder
¼ tsp salt
½ cup chocolate chips

Instructions

Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease or line an 8x8 pan (or use any oven-safe dish, even a round cake pan).
In a bowl, whisk melted vegan butter and sugar. Add eggs and vanilla, whisk until smooth.
Sift in cocoa, flour, baking powder, and salt. Stir gently until just combined.
Fold in chocolate chips.
Spread into the pan and bake 20–25 minutes, until edges are set and the center is slightly fudgy.
Cool, slice, enjoy!





I followed ChatGPT’s recipe (with a little improvisation because I realized I didn’t have vanilla extract). The result? Pretty solid brownies! They were rich, chocolatey, and definitely satisfied my sweet tooth.
 
I will say I had to cook it for an additional 10 minutes than the recipe called for. And they did not come out of the pan very nicely and kind of crumbled. But they were tasty!



I don’t think I trust ChatGPT as much as a recipe that has reviews and has been tried and test but it was convenient to have it customized to ingredients I had in my pantry. I think I would use it again to come up with a recipe I need in a pinch because it could save time looking through recipes and seeing if I have all the ingredients.



For me, it won’t replace an actual cookbook or a trained baker anytime soon, but it’s surprisingly handy for quick, low-effort ideas when you don’t feel like scrolling through food blogs.
Next time, I might try giving it weirder ingredients to see just how creative it gets.

title: Comparing ChatGPT 5.0 with a Mental Health LLM
text:
I have heard of some of my friends using ChatGPT as a tool to talk to and vent their feelings. So, I was already under the assumptions that people were using LLMs as therapists.
In my book Superagency, I was excited to read about how there are models being built specifically as therapists. However, Reid Hoffman highlights the failure of the specialized LLM, Woebot, to be emotionally attuned. Specifically, he gives this example:
Woebot: Okay, want to tell me more about what’s going on?

User: I’m feeling weird. It’s like I’m empty inside. When I look at the faces of my friends and family, I feel like they are empty as well. That’s why we cannot connect with each other. There’s nothing to hold on to.

Woebot: Sounds like you are dealing with feeling low…
That seemed a bit crass. In my experience, I thought of ChatGPT to be more adept so I wanted to test that same conversation with the 5.0 version to see if it responded in a similar way.

User: I’m feeling weird. It’s like I’m empty inside. When I look at the faces of my friends and family, I feel like they are empty as well. That’s why we cannot connect with each other. There’s nothing to hold on to.
ChatGPT: That sounds really heavy—and lonely. You’re noticing not only a kind of emptiness in yourself, but also projecting that sense onto the people around you, which must make it feel even harder to connect. Almost like everyone’s faces become hollow and there’s no anchor, no solid ground to hold onto.
I want you to know you’re not alone in feeling that way, even if it feels isolating. Sometimes those kinds of feelings can come with exhaustion, depression, or even just moments of disconnection where things lose their color and meaning.
I’m here with you in this moment. Can I ask—when did you first start noticing this sense of emptiness?


I thought this was a well-crafted response. In this test, I shared a heavy feeling of emptiness and disconnection with both Woebot and ChatGPT. Woebot’s reply felt generic and surface-level, simply labeling my mood as “feeling low” without much reflection. ChatGPT’s response, by contrast, directly acknowledged the depth of my experience, mirrored my words back to me, and gently normalized the feeling. It also invited me to explore when these feelings began, making the exchange feel more empathetic and human.

title: Prompting ChatGPT for marathon training plan
text:
I’ve been running consistently, but I’ve never had a formal marathon plan tailored to my goals and timeframe. Hiring a coach can be expensive, and online plans are usually one-size-fits-all.
So, I decided to experiment: what if ChatGPT 5 could be my running coach?



I wanted to have the final plan customized for me based on my current fitness and lifestlye. I started off by asking ChatGPT 5 what sort of information it wanted from me in order to make my training plan.

User: I want you to be my running coach to help me train for the 2025 Philadelphia Marathon which is in 2 months. Can you give me a list of questions that you would ask me in order to formulate a customized training plan for me?

ChatGPT: Perfect! To create a customized 2-month training plan for the 2025 Philadelphia Marathon, I’d want to get a full picture of your background, goals, lifestyle, and constraints. Here’s a list of questions I’d ask you as your “coach”:
🏃 Running Background

What is your current weekly mileage?
What’s the longest run you’ve completed recently?
Have you ever run a marathon before? If so, what was your time/experience like?
Do you have recent race times for shorter distances (5K, 10K, half marathon)?
Do you typically run on roads, tracks, or trails?

🎯 Goals & Expectations

What is your primary goal for the Philadelphia Marathon — finish strong, hit a specific time, or qualify for something (e.g., Boston)?
Do you have a target pace in mind for race day?
What’s more important to you: speed, endurance, or simply enjoying the experience?

🏋️ Strength & Cross Training

Do you currently do strength training or cross training (cycling, swimming, yoga, etc.)?
Are you open to incorporating strength/mobility sessions into your plan?

⏰ Schedule & Lifestyle

How many days per week can you realistically commit to running?
Do you prefer morning, afternoon, or evening runs?
Do you have any upcoming travel, work, or school commitments that may affect training?

🩺 Health & Injury History

Have you had any past or current injuries (knees, shins, ankles, hips, etc.)?
Do you have any health concerns I should keep in mind (e.g., asthma, anemia, nutrition issues)?

🥗 Fueling & Recovery

How’s your nutrition and hydration routine right now?
Do you have experience practicing fueling (gels, chews, hydration) on long runs?
How many hours of sleep do you typically get per night?

🌦 Race-Day Specifics

Have you run in Philadelphia before, or are you familiar with the marathon course?
Do you have gear preferences (shoes, watch, hydration belt/vest)?

💡 Personal Motivation

What motivates you most: following a structured plan, listening to your body, or running with others?
What do you hope to get out of this marathon beyond just finishing (confidence, health, community, fun)?


It gave me 22 questions to answer! I answered each of them to the best of my ability with hopes of having a very in-depth and tailored training plan.



8-Week Philadelphia Marathon Training Plan
(Starting Monday, Sept 15, 2025 → Race Day Sunday, Nov 23, 2025)













Week
M
T
W
Th
F
S
S




1 (Sept 15)
Rest / XT
6 mi easy
5 mi w/ strides
6 mi @ MP (8:00–8:15)
Rest
4 mi shakeout
Half Marathon Race


2 (Sept 22)
Rest
14 mi long run
6 mi aerobic
6 x 1k @ 10K pace
Rest
6 mi easy
5 mi recovery


3 (Sept 29)
Rest
7 mi easy
5 mi tempo (HM pace)
7 mi aerobic
Rest
5 mi easy
16 mi long run (last 4 @ MP)


4 (Oct 6)
Rest
8 mi aerobic
8 x 800m @ 10K pace
6 mi easy
Rest
6 mi easy
18 mi long run


5 (Oct 13)
Rest
7 mi easy
6 mi tempo (HM pace)
8 mi aerobic
Rest
6 mi easy
20 mi long run (last 6 @ MP)


6 (Oct 20)
Rest
18 mi long run (last 5 @ MP)
6 mi aerobic
10 x 400m @ 5K pace
Rest
6 mi easy
5 mi recovery


7 (Oct 27)
Rest
7 mi easy
5 mi tempo (HM pace)
6 mi aerobic
Rest
5 mi easy
14 mi long run


8 (Nov 3)
Rest
10 mi long run
6 mi aerobic
6 x 800m @ 10K pace
Rest
4 mi shakeout
5 mi recovery


9 (Nov 10)
Rest
5 mi easy
4 mi tempo
5 mi aerobic
Rest
4 mi shakeout
8 mi long run


10 (Nov 17)
Rest
4 mi easy
3 mi w/ strides
3 mi easy
Rest
2 mi shakeout
RACE DAY! 26.2 mi



Key: - MP = Marathon Pace (8:00–8:15/mi) - Tempo = Half Marathon pace (~7:55–8:00/mi) - Intervals = 10K pace (~7:40–7:50/mi) or 5K pace (~6:55–7:05/mi) - Easy/aerobic runs = comfortable conversational pace (~9:00–9:30/mi) - Long runs include fueling practice + hydration - Rest = rest day or optional cross training (bike, swim, yoga)



This experiment showed me how AI can make training feel more accessible.
While it won’t replace years of coaching expertise, it’s a surprisingly motivating and structured tool.
For now, ChatGPT is my new running buddy — and hopefully, it’ll help me cross the finish line in Philadelphia this fall.
